titles: Ontario Cobalt Exploration Update
bodyTexts:
BATTERY MINERAL RESOURCES CORP ("BMR-V") - Ontario Cobalt Exploration Update
Battery Mineral Resources Corp. ("Battery" or "BMR" or the "Company") is pleased to announce that drilling intercepted 4 main cobalt mineralized structures on the recently completed and initial diamond drill program at the White Reserve Project located about 120 kilometres northeast of Sudbury and 30 kilometers southwest of town of Elk Lake.
Highlights: //st * 17 drillholes completed for 1,838 meters ("m"); * Targets identified from recent three-dimensional model of historic
underground mine workings and results of a recent geophysical model; * Samples have been dispatched for assay and results are pending.
About the White Reserve program
The White Reserve property comprises 616 mining claims totaling 12,984 hectares of contiguous mining claims located in Banks, Barber, Speight, Van Nostrand and Whitson townships (Figure 1). Much of the White Reserve property was burnt by a devastating forest fire during the summer of 2018 (Photo 1). The 2018 fires severely limited access to the property with only a limited number of reconnaissance prospecting, geological mapping and rock sampling traverses completed.
In 2019 a grid-based geophysical three-dimensional distributed induced polarization ("3D IP") survey was conducted by Canadian Exploration Services. Limited rock grab sampling of rock dumps and surface outcrops yielded anomalous cobalt values ranging from 0.02% to 3.90% cobalt and 0.26g/t to 5.90g/t silver.
BMR compiled a 3D geological model of the historic workings and main vein structures to identify targets and design the drill program (17 drillholes / 1,838m). The drilling targeted both strike and vertical extensions of the main veins and two high chargeability induced polarization geophysical targets.
The four main east-west striking quartz-carbonate-silver-cobalt vein structures were drill tested. Several of the holes were also planned to test a north-south high chargeability 3D IP geophysical anomaly located just west of the old mine workings in the Nipissing diabase (Figure 2 and Table 1). Targeting was as follows: //st * Holes WRS20-001 - 004: Tested the #21 Vein * Holes WRS20-005 - 006: Tested the #14 Vein * Holes WRS20-007 - 008: Tested the #10 Vein * Hole WRS20-009: Tested IP Chargeability Anomaly &#7 Vein * Hole WRS20-010: Tested IP Chargeability * Hole WRS20-011: Tested the #7, #8 &#9 Veins * Hole WRS20-012: Tested the #10 Vein * Holes WRS20-013 - 014: Tested the #14 Vein * Holes WRS20-015 - 016: Tested the #7 Vein
Detailed core logging and sampling has been completed. Samples have been dispatched for assay. Results are pending.
Battery CEO Martin Kostuik states: "We are encouraged that the 4 main mineralized vein structures targeted by this initial drill test were intercepted as-planned. This drilling targeted the historic mine area which includes 5 production shafts operating until approximately 1940. There remains an additional six known cobalt occurrences at White Reserve to be explored. We look forward to receiving the assay results and continuing this exciting portion of our Northern Ontario cobalt exploration program."
Background
The White Reserve project comprises a 15 km long, north-trending belt of Proterozoic Nipissing diabase that hosts seven cobalt-silver occurrences including the historic workings known as the White Reserve mine (Figure 3 and Figure 4). The minesite is nestled in a north-south trending valley bounded by high ridges of diabase.
The White Reserve mine was operated from 1909 - about 1940. Early mine development included sinking of a shaft to 45m with two levels at 21m and 43m. Four additional shafts and a total of 1105m of lateral underground workings were developed. Historically, 24 vein zones were located on the eastern and western rims of the diabase- enclosed valley. The more productive veins, #7, #10, #14, and #21 were explored with shafts and open cuts, the 3 former veins developed on the west side, and the latter, on the east. White Reserve mine "reported historic" production amounted to 19,775 ounces of silver &452 pounds of cobalt from the #21 Vein.
The White Reserve project is dominated by a north-south striking Nipissing diabase sill, which intrudes quartzites and sandstones of the Lorraine formation, part of the Huronian Supergroup of the Cobalt Embayment. The diabase occurs mainly in the centre of the claim block. Regional north-south and northeast-trending faults transect the area.
Cobalt - silver mineralization is generally confined to the diabase in veins that parallel the numerous faults and structures. Cobalt - silver mineralization occurs as vein-filled fractures, ranging from hairline fractures to a maximum width of 0.08m. Vein selvages consist of epidote-hematite-altered zones. The dominant sulphide minerals are niccolite and smaltite, with minor amounts of native bismuth and silver. Disseminated cobalt sulphides are hosted in a granophyric phase of the Nipissing diabase. Additionally, disseminated cobalt-silver mineralization was noted up to 1.5 meters on either side of vein fractures.

Quality Control
Sample preparation, analysis and security procedures applied on the BMR exploration projects is aligned with industry best practice. BMR has implemented protocols and procedures to insure high quality collection and management of samples resulting in reliable exploration assay data. BMR has implemented formal analytical quality control monitoring for all of its field sampling and drilling programs by inserting blanks and certified reference materials into every sample sequence dispatched.
Sample preparation was performed by ALS Minerals Laboratories (ALS) in Sudbury, Ontario and sample analyses by ALS in North Vancouver, British Columbia. ALS analytical facilities are commercial laboratories and are independent from BMR. All BMR samples were bagged by BMR staff and delivered Upon receipt at the ALS Laboratory in Sudbury, samples were logged in a sophisticated laboratory information management system (LIMS) for sample tracking, scheduling, quality control, and electronic reporting. Samples were dried in special drying ovens prior to crushing. The samples were crushed to 70% ( -2 mm and a riffle split of 250 grams was then pulverized to 85% of the material achieving a size of (75 microns. These prepared samples were then shipped to the ALS Laboratory in North Vancouver for analyses by the following methods: //st * ME-MS61: A high precision, multi-acid digest including Hydrofluoric,
Nitric, Perchloric and Hydrochloric acids. Analysed by ICP (inductively
coupled plasma) mass spectrometry that produced results for 48 elements. * ME-OG62: Aqua-Regia digest: Analysed by ICP- AES (Atomic Emission
Spectrometry) or sometimes called optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES)
for high levels of Co, Cu, Ni and Ag. * Ag-GRA21: Silver by fire assay and gravimetric finish; 30-gram charge.
Weight. Used when samples contain ) 1500 ppm silver. * Au-AA25: Gold was analysed by a 30-gram fire assay method, followed by
AAS (atomic absorption spectroscopy).
Note that 48 element ICP trace element data was also collected and reported by the laboratory. Certified international standards were inserted into sample batches by ALS. Blanks and duplicates are inserted within each analytical run. The blank is inserted at the beginning, internationally certified standards are inserted at random intervals, and duplicates are analysed at the end of the batch.
Qualified Persons
P. J. Doyle, FAusIMM (#208850), Battery Mineral Resources Corp. - Vice President Exploration - Canada, supervised the preparation of and approved the scientific and technical information in this press release pertaining to the Canada Exploration Program.

About Battery Mineral Resources Corp
Battery is a multi-commodity resource company. Battery is engaged in the discovery, acquisition, and development of battery metals (cobalt, lithium, graphite, nickel &copper), in North America and South Korea. Battery is the largest mineral claim holder in the historic Gowganda Cobalt-Silver Camp, Canada, with various high-grade primary cobalt silver-nickel-copper targets located in the Cobalt Belt of Ontario and Quebec. In addition, Battery owns approximately 89.2% of ESI Energy Services, Inc., a pipeline equipment rental and sales company with operations in Leduc, Alberta and Phoenix, Arizona. Finally, Battery is currently pursuing a concurrent financing and acquisition to acquire the Punitaqui Mining Complex, a copper-gold mine located in the Coquimbo region of Chile.

titles: High Grade Au Mineralization on the Western Extension of Beardmore Geraldton Greenstone Belt, Ontario
bodyTexts:
TRANSITION METALS CORP ("XTM-V;TNTMF-0") - High Grade Au Mineralization on the Western Extension - of Beardmore-Geraldton Greenstone Belt, Ontario
Transition Metals Corp ("Transition", "the Company") is pleased to announce its summer prospecting and sampling work continues to support the interpretation that its Jolly Gold property covers the western extension of the prolific Beardmore-Geraldton Greenstone Belt (BGB) (Figure 1). The property covers a sulphide-facies iron formation that caps the northern assemblage of mafic metavolcanic flows overlain by intermediate pyroclastics. Gold deposits elsewhere in the BGB, such as the 4.5 Moz I&I Hardrock deposit under development by Greenstone Gold near Geraldton, are considered classic examples of epigenetic, non-stratiform, banded iron formation-hosted gold deposits. Other notable deposits within the BGB include the Brookbank (0.6 Moz M&I), the Sand River and Leitch Mine (past production of 0.9 Moz), the Northern Empire Mine and Sturgeon River Mine.
In July the Company completed a first pass mapping and prospecting program on Jolly Gold which included cutting and assaying of 114 channel samples on the historical Fat Beagle trench (Figure 2, Table 1) as well as collecting 82 prospecting grab samples across the 45.6 km2 property before work was halted due to local forest fire conditions. This work followed up on the initial property visit conducted in September 2020 (see November 24th, 2020 press release). Much of the property is covered by unconsolidated sediment and Nipigon diabase, limiting the exposure of the targeted Archean host rocks.
Channel sampling within the historic Fat Beagle trench returned very high-grade zones of gold mineralization, with assays of up to 146.5 g/t Au over 0.41 m, and 24.4 g/t Au over 0.61 m (Figure 2, Table 1). The best result from the 82 grab samples collected outside of the showing area returned was 1.35% Zn from an outcrop of sulphide facies iron formation (Figure 3).
CEO Scott McLean commented, "The results of the sampling in the historic trench and identification of prospective sulphide facies iron formation supports the interpretation that our claims cover the western extension of the prolific Geraldton-Beardmore gold belt and have the potential to host significant gold mineralization. This camp scale exploration opportunity has seen only limited exploration despite its' accessible location. We believe that the application of advanced exploration techniques including, biogeochemical surveys that have proven successful on our Wollaston Cu project will assist in advancing our understanding of the property's prospectivity and identify major target areas for further exploration including diamond drilling."

titles: Press Gallery
bodyTexts:
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: It's just really hard now to get an appointment. I think it's going to be really tricky.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: I needed to get tested on Friday, but I ended up having to wait until Monday to get tested. EVAN SOLOMON: Testing nightmares across the country, backlogs, waits, it's been a nightmare, frankly. Meantime, the prime minister tested negative for COVID-19 back in August. Prime minister said his test result came back just a day later. How did he get tested so fast? Did he use the private paid clinic that MPs are allowed to use? Erin O'Toole used one. Did the prime minister also use that? And should private testing clinics, you can get some in Quebec, across the river from where I'm sitting right now, for about $250, should those be allowed, or, as the Health Minister Patty Hajdu said yesterday, are those a violation of the Canada Health Act and a doorway to two tier healthcare? And if so, why do MPs get it? Let's dig in with the press gallery. Bob Fife, the Globe and Mail's Ottawa bureau chief is here, Emilie Nicolas reporter of Le Devoir is here, and Dr. Abdu Sharkawy, CTV News infectious disease specialist joins us. Bob, I'll start with you. First of all, do we know more about the prime minister's test? He wasn't very transparent when he got it or how he got it. Now what do you make, what do you make of this, these private clinics charging for a quick test to break the logjam?

ROBERT FIFE (Globe and Mail): Well the prime minister's office hasn't been very forthcoming about when he got that test, did he go to a private clinic, who did it? I suspect what happened is that he probably had the DND doctor, which travels with him, do the test, but they haven't provided with that kind of information. You know the problem we've had here is that governments had plenty of time to prepare for what everybody knew was going to happen in the fall, which was a second wave, a surge, and that we are facing that right now, and the governments did not prepare for that. But the solution is not to go to a two-tier system. The solution is to put more money into the system so that they can do proper testing. I don't think Canadians want to see a system where politicians jump the queue, or people with money can spend $250 and get a test, while everybody else cannot do that. So the onus lies on the feet of the politicians who did not properly prepare, and that we as Canadians have to demand more of our politicians to get this testing done. SOLOMON: Yeah. I wonder about the walk. The walk. Of course, Emilie, in Quebec, it's different after of course that legal case, the Chow Lui case, if people can't get expedient health care they're allowed to take alternative routes so people are getting it in Quebec. How is the debate around private testing for COVID playing out there? EMILIE NICOLAS (Le Devoir): Well it's important to understand that it's not just private testing. It's also all the normal surgeries, hospitals procedures that have been delayed because the hospitals are focused on COVID-19. So what you're seeing is a lot of folks who are actually paying because they've been waiting for so-called, you know, non-urgent surgeries, but they're still in pain, and so they turn to the private sector for that. So, really, I think it's, what's important to bear in mind is that whenever people have tried to privatize something, whether it be health care or schools, the first thing that they do is underfund the public system to make the public system inefficient and crappy in some way, and then that helps some of the public to be convinced that that they need the private option as well, right. So I guess that's what we're saying. There's no good option right now because the problem is upstream. The problem is why is it that we have a public health care system that cannot answer the needs of the Canadian population properly. SOLOMON: Yeah, the very people, Dr. Sharkawy, who are running and upholding the notion of public health care when it doesn't work, they become the very illustration of why some will argue you need private health care. You're on the front lines. Give us a sense of the test crisis, if it's a major failure, and what you make of it as a way out? DR. ABDU SHARKAWY (CTV News Infectious Disease Specialist): Well it absolutely a major crisis at this point in time. When you talk about a backlog of cases to be tested, you know, in the 80,000, 90,000 range, and concurrently having no effective tracing system at the same time, that's abject failure. You're in a situation now where the people who actually need to be tested are those that are in marginalized communities. Those that are disproportionately affected by this are those that don't have the resources available to them to advocate. They don't necessarily have the health literacy that many others do. And we've shifted to online appointments here in Ontario. I'm not sure that that's serving the population that is affected by this disease mostly here. SOLOMON: Doc, let me just quickly stay with you, because I just talked to the Liberal leader in Ontario, Steven Del Duca, and he's calling for restaurants, bars, and gyms in Ontario, in hot spots anyway, to close down for 28 days. There's a lot of debate about a second lockdown. Again, you're on the front line. Do we need it in certain places? SHARKAWY: I think at this point in time the evidence is abundantly clear. We can no longer continue to debate about whether this is an issue that continues to worsen. We have seen our hospitalizations increase slowly, but steadily, over the last week and a half. We know that hospitalizations and ICU admissions are the last indicators of disease progression within the community. And we know that venues such as bars and indoor dining in particular are those that help propagate transmission of this virus. That's an epidemiologic principle of reality that can no longer be denied. So I absolutely think we need targeted restrictions to be imposed without further delay, or we're going to make the situation much worse in the long run. SOLOMON: Bob, just the politics of this, politicians who maybe had a lot of confidence a month ago, is the length of the pandemic, is this changing the political response and the impact of this? FIFE: Well, look, I'm flabbergasted by this to be honest, because everybody had told us we're going to have a bad first wave, but the second wave is going to be worse, and it's going to come in the fall, and we're just seeing the early stages of it, because flu season is upon us as well. So the politicians have to get together, prime minister, he talks to the premiers once a week, he's got sit down with them and say, look, what resources do we need to solve this problem, and let's get to work to solving it. And to the doctor's point, if there are hot spots, then they should be closing down restaurants and bars in hot spots. This is like a forest fire. It blows up, you know, we can calm it down at some points, and other points, the wind comes up and it is blowing really badly and burning, and we, and this is what's happening in Toronto and the Ottawa area, and clearly they have to address this issue. But it takes political leadership to do so, and they've failed miserably over the summer months. SOLOMON: Just real quick, Emilie, I just got a couple seconds. You're living in the forest fire, you're in one of the red zones in Quebec. Are they doing, is Quebec doing anything differently than other provinces? NICOLAS: More things have been closed down already. The 28 days that is being suggested in Ontario is already in place, I'm living it right now. The one issue that I would say very quickly is that because there's no information on where the tracing is happening basically, how the outbreaks are happening, it's hard to justify why those measures are in place if you don't know that for example gyms are the problem, then you close gyms, then there's a backlash of people who are unhappy with that, so that's one of the issues, transparency. SOLOMON: All right. Guys, I've got take a short break. I know Emilie and Bob are going to stay with us. Just to use Bob's metaphor, doc, you're our firefighter in this, our viral firefighter. Good luck, and we really appreciate your work, your information and your work on the frontlines as they fire starts to burn. But we got to take a break. Coming up next, a funeral was held today for Joyce Echaquan. She's the woman who died in a Quebec hospital while hearing racist comments about Indigenous peoples. How pervasive is racism in the healthcare system? We break that down next. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

titles: Dr. Chirico gets majority of West Nipissing council’s support
bodyTexts:
West Nipissing council voted with a strong majority Tuesday against a resolution asking the North Bay Parry Sound District Health Unit to “immediately transition” out of COVID-19 shutdown extension. 
Deputy Mayor Yvon Duhaime was the lone member to vote in support of asking Dr. Jim Chirico, the Medical Officer of Health, to align the district with the provincial framework, including the reopening of toboggan hills, outdoor rinks, and snowmobile trails. 
The resolution, tabled by Mayor Joanne Savage in response to a widely-circulated letter by resident Rejean Venne, who cited statistics that argued the local health unit wasn’t basing its decisions on available information. 
Venne was also calling for a cost-benefit analysis to weigh the risks of COVID-19 against the toll on local businesses, increases in opiod deaths and overall impact on the mental health of residents. 
See: Our region needs to be treated more fairly when it comes to the COVID-19 response 
And: Parry Sound Chamber of Commerce demands data to justify extended lock down order 
“This is not going to resolve our situation,” Duhaime said of the current situation where other neighbouring regions have looser restrictions and more open economies. “We can’t stop this from happening (when people can bring the virus back such as the case at the North Bay apartment building) meanwhile everybody suffers.” 
Duhaime said he agrees with the mayor of Sudbury who wants to create a northern bubble to keep non-essential travelers out of the area. 
“In West Nipissing, we’ve done reasonably well, we’ve done everything humanly possible to keep everyone safe, but, unfortunately, you close the door in one area but you leave the windows open, then things can happen,” he said. “If we’re going to close it, let’s close it and do it properly.” 
Otherwise, Duhaime said, the extension of the shutdown merely “penalizes the businesses in our area.” 
Councillor Chris Fisher said it is “terrible with no end in sight, however … if we encourage Dr. Chirico to lift some rules and people start dropping dead around us, that’s a problem.” 
Fisher also noted that West Nipissing council “doesn’t have the same information he has.” 
Councillor Denis Senecal also supported the status quo of keeping the district under tighter restrictions “especially with that variant in North Bay.” 
Senecal said he’s satisfied with Dr. Chirico’s decisions that included closing snowmobile trails, outdoor rinks and toboggan hills even though most of the province didn’t do so. 
“I think we’ve been well served by Dr. Chirico, he’s kept us safe so far. To open it up now I don’t think it’s wise,” he said. 
Councillor Dan Roveda said it’s not council’s jurisdiction. 
“It’s the health unit’s responsibility to keep people healthy,” Roveda said, adding he supports the “radical” closing of potential gathering activities 100 per cent. 
“Dr. Chirico is trying to save lives. God forbid one of the variants get into our community, it would spread like a wildfire” like it did in North Bay, he said. 
Councillor Leo Mallette agreed with Venne’s points and helped bring the motion to the table but he appeared to recognize council’s lack of jurisdiction. 
Councillor Rolly Larabie said there’s no reason to discuss the resolution if they have no power to overrule Dr. Chirico. 
“It’s pointless, we can’t change his mind,” he said, suggesting instead that the resolution go to the emergency control group for review. But Jay Barbeau, chief administrative officer, said that group respects “incident command” management structures. 
Barbeau said they’d follow the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry decisions if it was a forest fire and the police if it was a criminal situation. 
“This is a health thing … and we tend to follow the direction of experts in those areas,” he said, adding a cost-benefit analysis would more likely be done at global level rather than a district health unit. 
Councillor Lise Senecal recognized that “everybody is sick and tired, getting cabin fever or whatever you call it … it’s not fun for everybody.” 
Senecal shared she’s been retired for a year and can’t travel but going against Dr. Chirico isn’t advisable, especially considering the aging demographic in the district that’s most vulnerable to the virus. 
Council can make decisions that prepare the municipality to open, such as giving staff the green light to get ready for outdoor rinks reopening or closing the arenas if it’s no longer feasible. 
Savage also said council should stick in its lane, although she’d like to see more communication between health unit districts and municipal leaders. 
“Our role is as ambassador … to tell people to follow the health regulations,” she said, which include for the North Bay and Parry Sound district to remain under lockdown until at least Monday. 
Dave Dale is a Local Journalism Reporter with BayToday.ca. LJI is funded by the Government of Canada.

titles: Bushfire aid begins at home
bodyTexts:
JAKARTA: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop says Australia will consider its own bushfire season before sending further resources to help Indonesia with its forest fire emergency.
Ahead of meeting her Indonesian counterpart Retno Marsudi on the sidelines of the Indian Ocean Rim Association ministerial meetings, Ms Bishop said Australia hadn't yet been asked to send aircraft again, but was ready to assist. "We will assess any request made of us, but most certainly in the context of our capacity to assist," she said yesterday.

titles: Hepburn park's fireless clean up
bodyTexts:
Forest Fire Management Victoria has begun mechanically removing fuel throughout the southern end of Doctors Gully in the Hepburn Regional Park instead of burning off.
The organisation met with residents and the Hepburn Shire Council earlier in the year to discuss options for the site's clean up after residents had expressed concern about the affect burn-offs would have on tourism in the region.
FFM Vic Regional Manager Forest and Fire Operations, Peter Kambouris said while planned burning would continue to be used, the absence of bark fuels in the area meant burning could be avoided in this instance.
The move come less than three weeks after Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley urged all regional Victorians to clean up ahead of the summer fire season.
Emergency services around Ballarat have already attended a number of grassfires , including a blaze at Meredith last Monday which burned through around 16 hectares of land.

titles: KILLER CONFLAGRATION
bodyTexts: A forest fire rages near the town of Sant Llorenc Savall, in north-eastern Spain. Five people were found dead on Monday after trying to flee their home. CNN Europe said the victims became trapped in smoke and died of asphyxiation. Their nearby farmhouse was not affected. The forest fire has forced at least 500 people to evacuate their homes.

titles: Burning ready to go after dry spell
bodyTexts:
Burn-offs around the North East are ready for ignition, as soon as the dry weather spell finally ends.
Forest Fire Management Victoria district manager Aaron Kennedy said smaller burns were targeted first, such as in Bonegilla last week and possibly Wangaratta Common in the coming days.
He said the burns program would be wide-ranging across the North East district and focused on protecting life and property in housing areas.
But FFMV was still wary of fire season, especially the chance of bushfires started by storms with a lot of lightning and very little rain.
Heavy spring rain caused extra grass growth, and fuel for fires, which had resulted in some callout for firefighters to bushland and private property to assist the CFA over the past six weeks.
"It's been quieter than previous years," Mr Kennedy said.
"The prolonged dry spell that we're experiencing has meant we have extremely dry forest fuels."

titles: Firewood collection season to start
bodyTexts:
The autumn firewood collection season will begin Wednesday, March 1.
During the season, people can collect firewood from within designated collection areas, with a limit of two cubic metres per day and a maximum of 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.
"Designated collection areas are put in place to protect sites of cultural and environmental significance," Forest Fire Management Victoria's Brady Childs said.
"Also, some households rely on firewood for winter energy so consider others when taking wood."
In red river gum parks, reserves and forests along the Murray River, collection will be restricted to residents of certain municipalities.
The felling of trees for wood is prohibited.
Officers will patrol parks, forests and reserves to ensure collections comply with regulations.
Permission from local government is needed for the collection of firewood from roadsides under their management.
VicRoads does not currently allow firewood collection on roadsides it manages.
The season will close on June 30.
For more information, visit the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning website or call 136 186.

titles: Night vision to assist fighting bushfires
bodyTexts:
A recommendation from the 2009 Bushfires Royal Commission was put into practice over Ballarat last week as night vision goggles were used to hunt for any fires ignited by lightning strikes.
An Emergency Victoria two-person pilot and crew used a Firebird 302 helicopter customised for night vision purposes for a two-hour reconnaissance mission over the Dandenong Ranges, Healesville, Mount Macedon, Wombat State Forest, south of Ballarat into the Brisbane Ranges and Plenty Gorge.
No fires were detected, but Forest Fire Management Victoria senior aviation officer Bryan Rees said the intent was to continue to build on existing operations while maintaining specialist skills.
"This is exactly the same as reconnaissance day operations that we do all the time - but just at night.
"There are the same challenges with day operations - for example, too much cloud or smoke are still limitations at night."
Operators of night vision goggles are specially trained and accredited personnel.

titles: Partners educate show patrons
bodyTexts:
THE Warrnambool Show is not all about fun, with two key agencies choosing the event to highlight their emerging partnership.
Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) has been established to fight fires on public land managed by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP).
FFMVic member Tasha Noss was on hand at the Warrnambool Show to help raise awareness of what role the group plays.
The FFMVic display was alongside that of the Hamilton CFA, a placement that was done by design.
"We will be working alongside the CFA in fire situations so it was a good chance for us to be side-by-side at the show," Ms Noss said.
"We are only a relatively new body. The show is a good community event with strong rural links.
"Given those links, we see it as the perfect place for us to spread the word about what we do."

titles: Campers advised to cease polluting
bodyTexts:
Visitors using free campgrounds in Grampians regional State Forests have been warned to clean up after themselves and take their rubbish home.
Forest Fire Management Victoria Regional Manager Peter Kambouris said authorised officers were noticing an increasing number of breaches of the law.
"Along with illegal campfires, the dumping of rubbish, damage to forest roads and vandalism is occurring," he said.
"What concerns us are those people not respecting the needs and expectations of other visitors as well as our fire crews.
"We have already experienced incidents this summer of campfires being left unattended and this week, bags of rubbish were left behind at vacant campsites.
"Knowing the rules for campfire safety, proper disposal of rubbish, and treating the landscape with respect is required."
Mr Kambouris said campers should use some common sense and set a good example. "People are urged to report illegal activities observed in state forests on 136 186," he said.

titles: Walking off the wars within
bodyTexts:
EMERGENCY service personnel met at Horsham's May Park on Friday to raise awareness for post traumatic stress disorder.
Country Fire Authority District 17 operations manager Dale Russell said firefighters and other emergency service personnel spent their professional lives looking after the community and it was important they also looked after themselves.
"It was about getting the message out there," he said.
"It wasn't a fundraising exercise; it was an awareness exercise."
The walk included 30 CFA staff alongside police, State Emergency Services, Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA volunteers relay walking around the park from 10am to 1pm.
The concept was inspired by Walking off the War Within - a major challenge in Ballarat inspired by the life and death of firefighter Nathan Shanahan.
Mr Russell said CFA management took the opportunity to speak to those gathered about the pressure of the job as well as the importance of looking after themselves, their families and each other.
"It went pretty well on the day," he said.
Mr Russell said members were unable to attend the Ballarat day so decided to share the message in the Wimmera.

titles: A spark from a slasher in an E...
bodyTexts:
A spark from a slasher in an Eldorado paddock is believed to have started a 10-hectare fire, which needed to be stopped by an aircraft water bomber.
About 16 CFA vehicles tackled the fire, which started on a property on Woolshed Road, outside the Eldorado township about 1.15pm.
Firefighters reported high flames in the area and the CFA issued an advice warning for nearby residents to be wary of smoke.
A helitack aircraft helped firefighters bring the incident under control in about 40 minutes, then Forest Fire Management Victoria members attended to put a break around the fire with a dozer.
It was travelling in a south-easterly direction towards Eldorado-Tarrawingee Road, but District 23 operations officer Trevor Ebbels said no homes were under threat.
"We believe it was started by a tractor and slasher," he said. "It's important that people understand that it is dry out there and there is danger on milder days as well as the very hot ones."

titles: Fireys starve bushfires of fuel
bodyTexts:
THE chances of a bushfire near Anglesea may have been reduced following a planned burn of 53ha yesterday.
More than 50 firefighters were in the area west of Anglesea for the burn, in preparation for the fire season.
Small fires were lit at Anglesea Heath, 2km from the town centre, just before lunchtime, to reduce bushfire fuel including large patches of heathland and eucalyptus trees.
Forest Fire Management Victoria manager David Rourke said reducing bushfire fuel would reduce the risk to people and property.
"Reducing bushfire fuel means bushfires are less intense, making it more likely that firefighters can contain them before they impact on people, property and the environment," Mr Rourke said.
"We understand that smoke from planned burns may cause concern for some people, but it's important that we take the chance to conduct these burns whenever weather conditions are suitable."He said smoke may be visible as crews monitored the site until it was deemed safe.

titles: Bruce to battle another season
bodyTexts:
This isn't the first time Bruce Sonogan has called the fire season "his last" - not even the Black Saturday bushfires could keep him away.
Mr Sonogan is in his fifth season as a Forest Fire Management Victoria project firefighter at Benalla and was awarded a National Emergency Medal in November.
The 59-year-old was part of the incident management team during the 2009 fires.
"I've seen most of the major fires - I was a front-line firefighter at Ash Wednesday and I've never seen anything like it," he said.
"We left our station and headed for Belgrave South; we could see flames twice the size of trees and there were vacant blocks among houses - unlike today - with spot fires everywhere.
"I have been on both sides of firefighting and I have an appreciation of how hard everyone works, both on the line and in the incident control centres."
The 2009 bushfires was one of only three events identified by the Australian Honours and Awards Secretariat as "nationally-significant emergencies".

titles: End is nigh for firewood collection
bodyTexts:
THE collection of free firewood on land managed by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) is about to come to a close.
Designated firewood collection areas will be closed from November 30 and it will be illegal for people to collect firewood on public land from that date.
Areas in Dartmoor, Heywood, Portland and Cavendish are among those on the free collection list, which can be found at the <url normalizedValue="http://www.delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood">www.delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood</url> website.
Forest Fire Management Victoria regional manager forest and fire operations Peter Kambouris said firewood collection may already have ceased in some parts of the state where supplies were exhausted or where rainfall or flooding had affected track conditions making collection unsafe.
"The public will be able to start collecting firewood again from designated firewood collection areas from 1 March, 2017, pending suitable conditions," Mr Kambouris said.
The pending closure of firewood collection comes as the CFA looks at its fire restrictions.
So far, no date has been set with late spring rain likely to see the restrictions not come into place until late December.

titles: Solidarity in fire fight
bodyTexts:
French and Italian air tanker fire planes have flown in to fight a huge forest fire raging in central Sweden, the worst seen in Scandinavia in 40 years, officials say.
Two FrenchCanadair CL-415s joined two similar Italian aircraft waterbombing the wildfire, which has been raging since July 31 near Sala.Sweden does not have air tankers of its own and has been using helicopters to help fire crews fight the blaze, which has destroyed 100sq km of forestry and claimed one life.

titles: Burn planned for McKenzie Creek
bodyTexts:
FOREST Fire Management and Parks Victoria will carry out a planned burn at McKenzie Creek, Three Bridges Road on Thursday.
The burn is scheduled to ignite at 12pm on Thursday and run through to Wednesday at 6pm, subject to favourable weather conditions.
The department said the 9.5-hectare burn would help reduce the risk of bushfire to people, property and communities.
The department said the burn would ignite two-kilometres south-west of Haven.
Smoke could be visible from Haven, McKenzie Creek and Three Bridges Road.
Parks Victoria advises people to stay away from areas where burns are planned or places recently burnt.
Parks advised people to be careful on the roads and aware of potentially lowered visibility and changed signed conditions.
Nearby residents should close all doors and windows and avoid hanging washing outside.
Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping ground and picnic sites may be restricted.
The Department of Health advises people that suffer adverse reactions to seek medical advice or call 1300 606 024.
For more information on the planned burn and traffic conditions visit parkweb.vic.gov.au/ or traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au

titles: Eye in the sky for burning
bodyTexts:
IN a first for the Otway Fire District, a drone was used to monitor fire activity- during a planned burn at Barwon- Downs Bushland Reserve yesterday.
The eye in the sky watched over more than 50 Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters as they carried out the operation.
The quadcopter can fly up to 100m above ground level and fly continuously for about 30 minutes.
FFMV Otway district manager David Rourke said the drone travelled above the fire during ignition, capturing extensive photography and video.
It is expected the trial technology will allow FFMV to deliver "more effective-" and "safer" burns.
"Once the burn is complete, the drone will be used to assess the area for hot spots by providing thermal imaging," Mr Rourke said. "It also delivers a live feed to a tablet, which is in the hands of fire staff on the ground." The planned burn was part of this week's general firefighter training for new Otway District project fire-fighters.To stay up to date on when and where planned burns are happening near you, go to vic.gov.au/planne d burn, download the VicEmergency app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

titles: Fire danger escalates amid extreme conditions
bodyTexts:
The fire danger indicators for south-west Victoria have skyrocketed because of the extreme conditions predicted tomorrow.
Modelling from the weather bureau shows the grass fire danger index for the Ballarat region is 258, and the forest fire danger index is 117.
In Hamilton, the grass fire risk is put at 208, while the forest fire risk is 83.
Fire weather forecaster John Saltenberger says the very high numbers are unusual.
"Something down closer to 40 or 50 would be what we might anticipate to be a typical summertime type of value," he said.
"But when critical combinations of wind temperature and humidity come together, such as what we'll see on Tuesday, they can take those indices and double them or triple them or more.

titles: Hay shed fire contained near Padthaway, in South Australia's south-east
bodyTexts:
Fire crews have contained a large hayshed fire at Western Flat near Padthaway in South Australia's south-east.
The Country Fire Service said four crews were at the scene on Broadview Road and they believe it will take days to put the blaze out completely.
Earlier in the day, the service was concerned the fire had the potential to spread into nearby native forest.
Fire crews have warned nearby residents that they expect the fire to generate large amounts of smoke in the area.
The cause of the blaze is unknown and the damage bill estimated to be more than $500,000.
Earlier this month a teenager from the Mount Gambier area was charged after a spate of suspicious haystack and shed fires in the Yahl and Glenburnie areas.

titles: KIWIS JOIN WYE RIVER BATTLE
bodyTexts:
NEW Zealand firefighters are set to join forces with Victorian crews tomorrow, with plans to bring the Wye River fire under control as quickly as possible.
An experienced team of Kiwi firefighters will assist by building containment lines around the Wye River-Jamieson Track fire.
The first deployment of 20 firefighters will work for three weeks doing ground work in steep and often inaccessible country.
"It's great to see Victoria working with agencies from abroad, sharing our knowledge and expertise to tackle what are very difficult fire conditions," Emergency Management Victoria commissioner Craig Lapsley said. "The attack on this fire is a real team effort, with over 400 personnel from CFA, the department's Forest Fire Management and Parks Victoria working around the clock."The Wye River-Jamieson Track fire was caused by lightning strikes on December 19, burning more than 2400ha and destroying 116 properties.

titles: Smoky forecast for the holidays
bodyTexts:
A smoky Easter could be on the cards for residents and visitors around Tawonga and Stanley.
Parks Victoria's forest fire management ignited the burns on Wednesday and Thursday in the hopes of protecting the towns from bushfires.
About 140 hectares of land was burned west of Stanley and 100ha west of Tawonga.
The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning's Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse said the burns needed to be conducted this week as it was the first opportunity following a hot, dry summer.
'They are important burns and we didn't want to miss the opportunity,' he said.
'People will see smoke in those areas.'
Parks Victoria had a target of about 17,500ha to burn in the Ovens district.
Last year a similar target was already half completed by Easter, but firefighters had not been able to start in 2016 at all before Wednesday's ignitions.
'We'll either be burning until the weather isn't right or until we reach our target,' Mr Hayse said.

titles: Bush blaze treated as suspicious
bodyTexts:
A FIRE that burned through 1ha of bushland at -Lysterfield Lake Park on Wednesday last week is being treated as suspicious.
A fire investigator was called in to determine the cause of the blaze, which started around lunchtime and tore through bushland north of Wellington Rd and west of Ryans Rd in Belgrave Heights.
The cause is still not known.
Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning spokeswoman Sally Bateman said a firebombing helicopter, bulldozer, 12 tankers and four trucks took half an hour to contain the blaze.
The department's forest fire management and the CFA fought the fire. It came as a planned burn scheduled for Mt Dandenong last Thursday was postponed.
Ms Bateman said the 8ha burn was put off due to the Lysterfield Lake Park fire, as well as forecast higher temperatures.
The burn has been removed from the list on the department's website, and a new date is not known.Street Watch, Page 6

titles: Air tankers fly in
bodyTexts:
STOCKHOLM: French and Italian air tanker fire planes have been sent to fight a huge forest fire raging in central Sweden.
The fire, burning near Sala since July 31, is the worst in Scandinavia in 40 years, officials say.
Sweden does not have any air tankers and has been using helicopters to help fire crews fight the blaze, which has already destroyed 100 square kilometres of forest.
The fire claimed its first victim on Tuesday when a 30-year-old man was found dead on a stretch of road that had been swept by flames. AFP

titles: Vic: Expert firefighters to provide specialist skills
bodyTexts:
A team of international forest fire experts has arrived in Victoria to boost specialist firefighting skills during the bushfire season.

   Seven firefighters from the US and Canada involved in the International Forest Fire Experts Program will spend two weeks with the Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) and Country Fire Authority in regional Victoria to provide leadership and technical support.
   The team will provide expertise to incident and area controllers, fire behaviour analysts, aircraft officers and logistics officers.
   Another group of up to 20 are due to arrive in January to remain in Victoria for the duration of the fire season.
   DSE chief officer Ewan Waller said on Tuesday the experts would be an invaluable addition to Victoria's firefighting capacity in the wake of the Black Saturday bushfires.
   "Bringing in international experts is the most effective short-term solution to providing immediate extra capacity and in future fire capability through lessons learned now," he said.

titles: Real needs sidelined
bodyTexts:
The wave of articles, such as "Direct Action could be converted to real policy" (AFR, April 29), echo the story of little Johnnie. His mum came into his room to find he had ripped up paper and scattered pieces across the room. She asked, "What are you doing?" He replied, "Keeping the elephants away." She said, "But there are no elephants here." He said, "See, it's working."
So as banknotes continue to be torn up to fight the red herring of "carbon", a will-'o-the-wisp imaginary elephant, real issues are sidelined - punitive taxation, inadequate infrastructure (roads, bridges, dams, ports), hopeless town planning, insufficient drought, flood and forest-fire proofing - and remain underfunded or unfunded. Where are our priorities?
John McRobert
Indooroopilly, Qld

titles: A price for bush living
bodyTexts:
Bushfires are inevitable and necessary for our particular type of flora, so there needs to be fires from time to time. People and property do not need to suffer destruction or death, if the powers that be enforce some rules about how people live in the bush. It seems that we need a fuel exclusion zone of some size around all towns, hamlets and houses in fire risk areas.
This raises the question: why should the house owners who make the logical decision to live in areas that are not in a non-defendable fuel and forest fire area, pay a royalty on insurance to support all those who don't?
I think it would make more sense for the government to clear the fuel away and let the people who still wish to live in the bush pay their own way. Thus leaving more money in the pockets of the logical majority.
Roger Wolfe
Balwyn, Vic

titles: Bushfires on all fronts send Californians packing
bodyTexts:
FIREFIGHTERS battled on Thursday to douse a series of wildfires fuelled by high winds, scorching temperatures and dry vegetation, which have forced tens of thousands of Californians to flee their homes.
A blaze scorching sections of the Angeles National Forest, in southern California, two huge infernos in the central part of the state and another fire further north have displaced entire towns.
"Our fire activity has definitely picked up in past weeks in number and severity," said Daniel Berlant, a spokesman for the Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.
The Angeles forest fire - dubbed "Blue Cut" - has devoured 12,545ha and is only 4 per cent contained.
The fire has been spreading at such an alarming pace that it appears as if it were "running at you", according to Michael Lopez, a spokesman for fire information website Inciweb.
More than 82,500 people potentially in Blue Cut's path are under evacuation orders.
About 1600 firefighters are committed to Blue Cut, while 5000 are battling the larger Soberanes fire, which has charred 32,000ha in the Big Sur tourist region, further north.Since the beginning of the year, 4600 fires have ripped through 120,000ha of Californian scrub and forest.

titles: Eight crews control blaze
bodyTexts:
FIVE rural fire crews and three urban fire crews battled a bushfire which broke out about 2am Monday in the Samford Valley.
A Department of Community Safety spokesman said the medium-sized (200m x 200m) slow-moving forest fire in bushland at Closeburn, near McDowells Rd and Mt Samson Rd, was no threat to property, but still advised nearby residents to review bushfire survival plans as a precaution. The blaze was under control by about 9.30am Monday. A smoke haze was expected to affect the area throughout Monday and residents were told to keep doors and windows closed, and keep respiratory medication nearby.

titles: FIREFIGHTERS TO MONITOR SITUATION IN TUAN
bodyTexts:
BRISBANE, Queensland, Nov. 11 -- The Queensland Department of Community Safety issued the following news release:
The forest fire burning in Tuan has been contained. Firefighters re-enforced containment lines overnight and will continue to monitor the situation throughout today. Smoke may still be seen in the Tuan area and motorists are advised to drive to conditions. People with respiratory conditions should also take the necessary precautions and keep windows and doors shut. titles: SNAPSHOTS
Vic: International bushfire crews to arrive in Victoria
bodyTexts:
About 120 international firefighters and recovery specialists will arrive in Victoria over the next week to help local crews battle the worst bushfires in Australia's history.

   The contingent from New Zealand, the United States and Canada will bring a range of firefighting and recovery skills, Andrew Graystone, Forest Fire Management Group international liaison officer, said.
   "We are very grateful for the additional skills and knowledge that these people will bring to our firefighting response and recovery," Mr Graystone said.
   Fifty-two specialist aircraft operators, firefighters and supervisors will arrive from New Zealand on Friday night and a further 60 specialists from the US will arrive on Sunday.
   The US contingent are experienced in tall forest firefighting, burnt area recovery, bulldozer management and incident management roles.
   The burnt area recovery team will be able to help assess and rehabilitate any impact on water catchments.
   Nine Canadian specialists will arrive in the middle of next week.
   The Forest Fire Management Group comprises officials from state and territory environment, forests, parks and wildlife departments.

titles: Fed: Aussie experts may join firefighting effort in Greece
bodyTexts:
Australia has offered to send specialist fire and aviation experts to Greece to help deal with the forest fire emergency there, Prime Minister John Howard says.

   More than 60 people have been killed since devastating fires broke out in Greece five days ago.
   Mr Howard today said four Australian experts could be sent to Greece.
   "The Australian expertise being offered includes two bushfire management officers (a high-level incident controller and a senior operations officer), a bushfire investigation officer, a forest fire behaviour expert and an aviation management expert," he said in a statement.
   "Australian officials will work closely with Greek authorities to ensure Australia provides the most appropriate and useful support possible.
   "The thoughts of the Australian Government and all Australians remain with the people of Greece at this difficult time."
   The Australian government had previously announced it would donate $3 million to assist the firefighting and recovery operation in Greece.

bodyTexts:
A US federal grand jury has indicted Australian rugby player and IVF geneticist Michael Quinn on charges of attempted child sex trafficking and travelling with the intent to engage in illicit sexual conduct. (LEGAL: US QUINN (with file pics))

   JAKARTA, June 21 AAP - The father of a woman allegedly murdered with a cyanide-laced coffee has hit out at an agreement between Australia and Indonesia that his daughter's accused killer would not face the death penalty. (LEGAL: INDON POISON Wrap (with pics, video))

titles: The damage this week
bodyTexts:
Victoria: More than 45,000 hectares burnt in Gippsland in 48 hours; 70 trucks on the scene; 200 personnel; two relief centres established in Sale and Traralgon.
NSW: 95 fires burning, 14 out of control, 100,000-plusha burnt, Siding Spring Observatory damaged, 51 homes and 50 sheds around Coonabarabran destroyed; 650 firefighters and more than 200 trucks on patrol.
South Australia: 10,000 fire-fighters on standby; north of Adelaide, the Bundaleer Forest fire burned more than 2300ha.

titles: Another hot one
bodyTexts:
WIMMERA authorities have warned people to take extra care tomorrow with a severe fire danger rating forecast.
An extreme forest fire danger index is also forecast.
Wimmera land and fire services manager Russell Manning of the Department of Sustainability and Environment said it was highly likely that a total fire ban day would also be declared for tomorrow.
An official decision will be made this afternoon. "The forecast for Horsham is in the low 40s, with single-figure relative humidity," Mr Manning said.
